chapter.para: The Scheduler Eclipse Plugin is available in two forms :

listitem.para:
A
Java stand alone application
based on
Eclipse Rich Client Platform (RCP)
, available for any platform (Windows, Linux, Mac OSX, Solaris, ...)

A set of
Eclipse
plugins
: with all the functionalities within the stand alone application, enhanced with a tool that makes easier the scheduling and monitoring of jobs and applications.

info.title: Starting the Scheduler Graphical User Interface

section.para:
Depending on the way you get the Scheduler plugin, just follow one of this step :
If you are using the stand alone application, just start it using the provided executable. ("Scheduler" on unix, "Scheduler.exe" on Windows).
If you are using the Eclipse plugins set, just installed it as an eclipse plugin and restart Eclipse. Then select the Scheduler Perspective.
Then, Window->Open Perspective->Other...->Scheduler (it could be already opened as it is the default perspective).
Once started, the first screen to be displayed is the following one : Scheduler welcome screen
A Scheduler may already be started before connecting the Scheduler GUI. If no scheduler has been started, please refer to .

To connect to an existing Scheduler, just right click on the empty area in the middle of the windows, then click on "Connect the ProActive Scheduler" in the context menu as shown below : Scheduler connection (1)
Some informations are now requested in order to establish the connection : Connect to scheduler dialog

Enter required informations about the remote scheduler, and click OK. The URL is composed of the protocol, the host name on which the Scheduler is started and the port on which it is listening. Then enter your user/admin name and password.

Note: If you check "log as admin" and your login is an admin one, you'll be able to do more actions than an "simple" user (see ). The connection right is performed by the Scheduler itself, you won't be able to connect as admin with a 'user' name.

The Scheduler plugin provides the
Scheduler
perspective
displayed in the .

This perspective defines the following set of
views :

listitem.para: The Jobs view: shows pending, running and finished jobs in the scheduler.
The Console view : shows jobs standard and error output (on demand).
The Tasks view : displays detailed informations on tasks contained in the selected job.
The Users view : displays informations about connected user.
The Jobs Info view : displays all informations of the selected job.
The Result Preview view : displays a textual or graphical preview on the selected task result.
A Control panel is provided at the top right of the windows in order to manage jobs and the Scheduler itself.

section.para: The main view is obviously the jobs one :
The control panel (on upper right) is describe in the

This view is composed of 3 panel which represents pending, running and finished jobs. In each panel you can watch many different informations about jobs, as their state, name, IDs, progress, etc... It is also possible to switch between vertical panel presentation and horizontal panel presentation as we'll see later.
In each panel, the list of jobs can be ordered by column.
This view displays selected job standard and error output (only on demand).

This view provides many informations on every tasks composing a job as :
The task id generated by the Scheduler
The task state to know if it is finish, running, etc...
The task name given by the user
The host name on which the task is executed
The task started time
The task finished time
In the column "Re-run", the first number represents how many times the task HAS already BEEN re-executed, and the second number how many times the task CAN BE re-executed
The user description of the task
In this view, the list of tasks can be ordered by column.

This view provides many informations on the selected job as :
The job id generated by the Scheduler, can be useful to get the result of your job outside the GUI.
The job state to know if it is pending, running, paused, etc...
The job name given by the user that submit this job
The current job priority (this can be changed to accelerate the execution)
The number of pending tasks
The number of running tasks
The number of finished tasks
The total number of task composing the job
The job submitted time
The job started time
The job finished time
The user description of the job

This view displays the result of the selected task (selected in task view), according to the ResultPreview field. This preview is powerful because of the generic way that will be used to perform the display. It is possible to redefine the displaying behavior by implementing the ResultPreview abstract class. Using this mechanism, it is possible to use an external tool or soft to display the result like an image viewer for picture.

This part explains the using of the control panel available at the top right of the Scheduler. The control panel goal is to manage the different jobs and the Scheduler itself. Let's start with the possibilities offer to a user.

itemizedlist.listitem: [1] Connect/Disconnect the Scheduler : use this button to display the "Connect to scheduler" dialog in order to establish a connection to a remote ProActive Scheduler. Once connected this button can disconnect from the currently connected Scheduler.

[2] Switch between vertical and horizontal jobs view : use this button to switch between the view that display the three list of jobs vertically and the one that display them horizontally. Horizontal view can be used to see more informations about the listed jobs but less jobs can be seen.
[3] Enlarge the job queue of your choice : use this button to enlarge the queue (pending/running/finished) of your choice. This will display the selected view in the whole space.

[4] Submit a new Job : use this button to submit a new job to the Scheduler. This action will request you for a job XML descriptor. If you don't know how to create such a descriptor, please refer to .
itemizedlist.para: For the next actions, note that you can also interact with the jobs that YOU submitted (you are the owner). To use these actions, just select a job and click on the desired button. Multiple selection is allowed.
itemizedlist.listitem: [5] Pause/Resume a Job : use this button to pause a pending or running job, and to resume a paused job. Note that it is not possible to pause a running task. So once a job paused, each running task will be finished. If a task has to restart for any reasons, it will be paused instead of restarted.

[6] Select Job priority : use this button to change the priority of your job. Allowed priorities for a user are :
Normal.
Low.
Lowest.

[7] View selected job output : use this button to view the selected job output. Job output is in fact the output that comes from the different tasks from both standard output and standard error stream.
[8] Kill the selected job : use this button to kill a job. The job will be terminated immediately, removed from the queue where it was, and its results will be lost.

section.para: All these actions that can be performed in the control panel can be also executed from the right click context menu. To view the result of your task, select one in the tasks view and the result preview will be executed automatically.

All actions allowed in user mode are also allowed in Administrator mode. Moreover you can execute any action on any job even you aren't the owner of this job. It is also possible to an administrator to do the following operations :

itemizedlist.listitem:
[6] Select Job priority : use this button to change the priority of a job. Allowed priorities for an Administrator are the same as the user plus the following one :
Idle. Priority lower than the 3 User priorities.
High. Priority higher than the 3 User priorities.
Highest. Highest priority that can be affected.
[A] Stop the Scheduler : This action places the Scheduler in a mode where no job can be submitted anymore until a restart. Nevertheless, all running tasks will be terminated.
[B] Freeze the Scheduler : The behavior is the same than the stop button except that job can still be submitted.
[C] Pause the Scheduler : This action put the Scheduler in a Pause state. Job can be submitted again but no job will go to the running queue. Every running jobs will terminate.
[D] Resume the Scheduler : Put the Scheduler into the normal scheduling mode : Started. This action can be performed when the scheduler is Frozen or Paused.

[E] Shutdown the Scheduler : Put the Scheduler in its shutdown sequence. Submitting job is no longer available. It will wait for every pending and running jobs to be terminated. Once done, the Scheduler will shutdown and disconnect.
[F] Kill the Scheduler : Force the Scheduler to terminate immediately. This action kills every tasks and jobs, get the resources back to the Resource Manager and kill the Scheduler.

section.para: This conclude the usage of the ProActive Scheduler Eclipse Plugin. Note that you can connect the same existing Scheduler with more than one interface on more than one host if you want to monitor it from different host.
